I agree and disagree. I think there should be a setting for this.
You should be allowed to choose to spawn nether or over world

I think it should be an option as everyone else seems to be saying, this is because it will eather affect seeds or be an unavoidable possibly when generating a new world which may be annoying for players who want to play a cirtain way.
This should be a setting. Imagine spawning in only to get eaten by eight hoglins. Not everybody is professional enough to handle such a challenge.

I think the point of the nether update is not only to make the Nether livable, but a valid spawn location for players.

Spawning in the Nether should be a little rare, maybe 20% of all worlds start in the Nether, or to make it more interesting, spawn locations should be chosen by having an equal chance at spawning in any biome (except the End as that hasn't been updated yet) so that since there are less Overworld biomes than Nether biomes, the chance of spawning in the overworld would be higher even though there would still be a chance to spawn in the Nether.

As content creators we need the options to make worlds in which the player starts in nether (in some controlled environment).

 

But wihtout this settings option we need to make workarounds of starting in overworld and then teleport the player to nether, which gives an extra step in the game flow that shouldnt be there.

Please give us the option to make players (local and visitors) to spawn by default in nether.

Maybe if a chunk has been filled for about 70% to 80%, it would store that chunk. Not on servers, as things can get a little hectic on there when it comes to crops.

Same problem, different approach:

When loading a chunk with crops inside, the game checks, how long the chunk has been unloaded and occasionally increases the growth state

This really discourages players from exploring other areas as your home base is just shut down when away. It's the same with Phantoms.

 

It should be handled like in Clash of Clans. When leaving a chunk save the current time. Upon reactivation of the chunk advance the simulation according to the elapsed time.

392663256311
That would be pretty neat, too. It would certainly add a factor for players to consider before engaging a group of mobs on top of everything else, and force players to think and act quickly about how they engage them.

A few additions to the idea (couldn't fit it all in one place due to the character limit)

-Give all potion effects in the game's code a craftable potion. Potions of Absorption and Health Boost, for instance, don't need to have a simple crafting recipe by any means, but implementing their effects would be crucial given how much damage you could take with just a single attack. Splash Potions of Blindness could be used to shorten a mobs line of sight by half or even temporarily disable their pathfinder. More on this in another suggestion.

-Add mini-boss mobs and boss mobs that only spawn in Master level difficulty. These can be mobs that spawn exclusively in generated structures such as dungeons and stronghold, or even in the middle of the Overworld in broad daylight. Their inclusion could introduce new mob drops, materials, weapons, tools, and armor that can only be acquired at this difficulty. More specific ideas in future suggestions.

My main issue with this idea is that it is ultimately biased. I realize you tried to make it as fair as possible from your point of view, but it ultimately still favors one side over the other. In the end, you are still being punished for not eating a diverse diet. A better compromise would be something that rewards players who have diverse diets with new advantages not currently in the game. Otherwise, you're essentially just forcing players to eat well if they want to sprint or regenerate health, things that were already possible before, without needing a good diet. I will say, however, that this was a very well organized suggestion that you clearly put some extra effort into, which I can certainly appreciate. I just ultimately disagree.

You've almost understood my idea. Diet would not have an effect on your ability to sprint or regenerate health under my proposal.

Instead, my proposal makes it to where if you eat a poor (not diverse) diet, performing actions such as sprinting and regenerating health would deplete saturation faster than if you ate a healthy (diverse) diet. That's it.

And even then, if your saturation depletes faster than usual, how would you respond? By simply eating more of whatever food you have stacks upon stacks of. So it's not nearly as much of a "punishment" as you might think, and it's specifically designed to avoid forcing players to eat a diverse diet if they don't want to.

It's hard to accept your statement that I'm biased. I'm only biased against the way the game is right now because I think the ability to survive on nothing but thousands and thousands of a single food is boring, shallow game design. After all, if I weren't "biased" in this way, this wouldn't be much of a suggestion, right?

Thank you for being kind even when you disagree with me, though. Props to you for being a fair commenter.

Maybe I didn't realize you did say this, but maybe it's something you can toggle, so if you want to use this and have this challenge, then it's something you can have. OR if you really really don't want it, go back to the old play style of minecraft. This is kind of like turning off and on weather, changing the difficulty and other things.

I would like to see something implemented to get players to eat more foods, but I agree more with Gabriel Irvin's idea of a system that rewards players that eat diverse foods. I think that different food types should give players small benefits, and eating a healthy range of foods should add an additional benefit. I do like your tastiness gauge idea, though. I think it is a great way to show players how healthy they are.

This could go two ways if added. It could make lots of food items ignored for restoring a lot of nourishment, or this could not effect the game at all, making it useless to add. I like the thought and effort put into these posts, but I think that the hunger bar is enough.
393338237792 I don't understand any of what you just said, please explain more clearly

I like your idea, and I wanted to comment on the adjustments I'd make to your system.

First, I think the nourishment level should start at 1 and go up to 3.  Level "1" would cause hunger to increase at the exact same rate it does today.  Whenever you respawn, the nourishment level goes back to 1.  This is so that players like me don't get a reward from killing themselves whenever they're hungry.  The nourishment level shouldn't go below 1, so that people who only eat one food don't find it easier than it usually is.

Second, I think there should be a fourth "taste tier," a blue dot, which represents absolutely delicious.  Every time you respawn, a set of random foods would be chosen that you absolutely crave.  These would start out blue and never get any less tasty than green.  If you eat enough blue foods, you can even boost your nourishment above 3, maybe to 3.5 or 4.  Also, enchanted golden apples would always be blue, and rotten flesh, pufferfish, etc. would always be red.

I hope you like my thoughts on your idea, and I wish that this post would get more attention.

I really like this idea (I was thinking about it myself which is why I looked up this post), but I was thinking that there could be some other things. First, the dispenser should only use the tool if it is appropriate for mining the block in front of it. Additionally, the dispenser should be able to use the right click function of the tool if it is unpowered before the block is broken or just still there. And finally, if there are multiple tools that the dispenser can use for the left/right click function (e.x. it contains a shovel and a hoe and is facing a dirt block, or two pickaxes and facing stone), it will choose a random one to use.

This would be a neat enchantment, as long as it isn't overpowered.  According to the wiki, the current range is 4.5 to 6 blocks depending on the version and input methods.   It might be reasonable if each level increased the range by 2 blocks.  So level 3 would double or more than double your breaking range.

But not for swords etc., the hackers Will use IT with reach hacks...

ClayGoddessSari: you’re right, it shouldn’t be OP but it should be enough to be a helpful and reliable enchantment. Double the distance does sound good to me.

Quinten van Bruggen: that’s my thought process with this as well. This is a great addition for mining/log breaking, but it should have absolutely no impact on melee performance & range. This is strictly for block breaking.

Mobius 762: I originally proposed that you could break the largest spruce trees without building, though I understand that may be a little too OP. But, what you’re suggesting really doesn’t give much of an advantage, and I don’t think people would really ever go for the enchantment at that point. When I thought of this, I figured it should be at least 3 levels and 1 block per level, though I would be happy with Mojang adopting this idea in any state (and how the see fit). Thanks for supporting my idea though, as well as every person who has voted and commented thus far and anyone who will be voting and commenting in the future. I was not expecting the enthusiasm I have gotten from the Minecraft community on Reddit and on here.

I have ideas for the story: 

You can only find the first traces of it in ruins, temples, mansions, etc. (but not in villages) , where there are books in the chests, filled with lost bits of the past. The Nether has nothing to do with it yet. You go to the end, defeat the Ender Dragon, and in a short first part of the credits, it is told to you by ”them” (Endermen) that you have finally freed them form their evil master. They now lay the fait of the world in your hands by letting you take ”it” (the Dragon Egg) with you, telling you that there is more evil hiding in ”on the other side” (in the Nether). Then, if you go to the Nether, you can now find Endermen fighting against Wither Skeletons. As soon as there are no Wither Skeletons left, all blazes would fly to the portal and create the ”Blaze King” (some kind of giant, red Blaze Boss). All Endermen assemble there and (eventually with the players help) defeat him. He drops a book called the ”king’s log”, where the whole story is written down...?
The whole point of Minecraft is that it does not have a story already written for you.  Instead, you must write the story yourself.

@William Miller Though it would be cool if the player could discover a different story than just writing his own. It wouldn’t be like story mode, but just books in chest and bossfights or other special events.

The books could also be how you get knowledge. (How to build a portal, how to tame wolfs and cats)

I am against the idea of a full-on storyline, which would take from the 'sandbox' element the game revolves around, but certainly not against some story elements scattered around the world. My suggestion would be this - diaries.

Diaries could be found in most generated structures, as a rare item in loot chests. For example, there could be a diary in a shipwreck map chest. As well as detailing the tales of long-dead adventurers, some diaries would contain the location of other structures within their pages. For example, a shipwreck diary might have the location of an ocean monument.

As well as diaries, they could add a new village structure - the traveller's hut. The traveller's hut would always contain a chest with a diary in, which would contain a location in, for either a jungle temple, desert temple, woodland mansion or stronghold (very rare). 

Locations in diaries could be transferred into explorer maps by combining the diary with an empty map in the crafting area. This would not use up the diary, but the map would become the relevant explorer map.

I appreciate the civility of your tone as well as your willingness to see both sides - not often seen when discussing these kinds of things. I think your compromise is a good one, so I voted. Can't wait to see what Mojang does with the next overhaul!
I still hope that they keep the combat system for bedrock, but I would not be too upset if it was updated to this system.

The problem with this is 3 quick hits is more powerful than 1 strong hit. How many spam-clicks can you do before attack meter fills up? So technically, this suggestion is equivalent to bringing back 1.8 combat, via making 1.9 version useless.

I'd prefer a world where spam-clicking isn't the way to deal the most damage. I'd like the system where the weapon charge stays, but an attack only takes say 33% off the charge, instead of 100%. This would allow 3-spam clicks which deal twice the weapon damage in total to be dashed out quickly, in exchange for having to wait longer before the next attack to be effective. Another person can wait the meter to fill up to deal a second full powered attack after their first. The percentage of power used and the speed of the charge bar filling up can be adjusted so that people who want to spam-click are satisfied with the amount of hits they can get in quickly and still feel like they are dealing damage, and the DPS of two approaches are roughly equivalent.
